fields.description:
Same as previous bug report - https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/JIM-395

Importing from Trac it appears that it is not importing any attachments that have spaces within the files names. The spaces are replaced with "%20"
fields.summary: Regression: Attachments with file names using spaces (or brackets in file name) not found during import.
Redmine Importer inconsistently maps issues status
User gets an unclear error message while importing CSV file into existing project
If a voter can not be resolved, the voters listed after it are also dropped

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64738].
  {panel}

It seems that is not possible to keep the assignee as Unassigned while doing a JSON import. 

I tried setting assignee: 
assignee: null
assignee: "Unassigned"
assignee: ""
(assignee missing from the JSON)

All of these to use the auto-assign rule of the project, and you end-up with issues owned by the project lead.
fields.summary: JSON import does not keep assignee Unassigned

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64736].
  {panel}

The Bugzilla Import using the JIM documentation currently states the following about Bugzilla version support, which is misleading to customers:
bq. Version 4.1 or later of the JIRA Importers plugin is compatible with Bugzilla 2.20 to 4.0.2. 
Actually the latest version of the JIM plugin is already 6.3.x and support up to the latest Bugzilla versions 4.4.x.

It would help customers to update this docs with the latest Bugzilla version support information.
fields.summary: Update the supported Bugzilla versions in the Importing Data from Bugzilla documentation

{code}

I'm using the URI attachment method with "file:" URIs. The files themselves (in the import/attachments directory) so all have unique names (in my case, I'm using the UUID of the source attachment record), but the "name" property of the ExternalAttachment beans in the issue are duplicated.

I've worked around this by detecting the condition and generating unique names, but the importer should probably follow the same rules as Jira itself, which does not insist on unique attachment names within an issue.
fields.summary: Error when importing an issue with attachments with duplicate filenames

fields.description: When the JIM plugin creates issues, it does not seem to generate any Issue Created events that other event listeners can listen to. This means that any other add-ons are unable to perform actions that they might otherwise taken upon issue creation.
fields.summary: No Issue Created events are generated for issues created by the importer

fields.description:
This issue affects FogBugz On Demand (and possibly FogBugz for Your Server too - although I haven't tested this one yet).

How to replicate this issue:
# Commence the FogBugz On Demand (or possibly the FogBugz for Your Server) Import Wizard.
# Select an existing project that uses (for example) the *Default Workflow Scheme*.
# On the subsequent *Setup field mappings* step, select a new workflow scheme (with completely different statuses).
# On the next *Setup value mappings* page, map statuses in the newly selected workflow scheme (which are not available in the selected project's current workflow scheme).
# Begin the import and JIM bombs out - presumably because the statuses you mapped don't match those of the selected project's current *Default Workflow Scheme*.

*How to resolve...*

Place some validation logic in such that when a user selects an existing project, either of the following happens:
* On the *Setup field mappings* step, if a workflow scheme other than the selected project's workflow scheme is selected, display a warning message on the subsequent step telling the JIRA admin that they cannot proceed because of that situation. This is what the Bugzilla importer currently does.
* *(Even better solution)* --- On the *Setup field mappings* step, don't allow the JIRA admin to select a workflow scheme, by hiding this option at this step if an existing JIRA project was selected earlier on in the wizard.
fields.summary: A JIRA admin can still select a workflow scheme after choosing an existing JIRA project to import issues to, which leads to big problems.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The External System Import screen on JIRA Core offers options that seem not to be implement because they go to CSV Import screen after selected

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have a JIRA Core (Cloud)
# Go to the External System Import screen
# Select one of the following options:
## Microsoft Excel
## Microsoft TFS
## Rally
## VersionOne
## Youtrack
## Axosoft
## Basecamp

h3. Expected Results
Be directed to the corresponding import option for the selected tool.
h3. Actual Results
Is directed to the CSV File import screen.
fields.summary: External System Import on JIRA Core offers invalid options

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64730].
  {panel}

Importing a Remaining Estimate using a CSV shows as a change in the issue history. The change in issue history shows that both the Remaining Estimate and the Original Estimate have changed
 * New Value for both = Remaining Estimate imported from CSV

The field values shows correct. The Original Estimate continues to show the value prior to the import. The Remaining Estimate shows the value imported.
h3. Steps to Reproduce:
 * Create issue with Original Estimate and different Remaining Estimate
 * Export to CSV
 * Change Remaining Estimate in CSV
 * Import from CSV choosing Summary, Issue Key, Remaining Estimate.
 * Review the history and estimate field values on the issue

h3. Expected Behavior

Change History shows that Remaining Estimate changed without showing any change to Original Estimate
fields.summary: CSV import of Remaining Estimate overwrites Original Estimate in issue history

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64725].
  {panel}

When I try to import an issue with 2 attachments and when these 2 attachments have the same name, JSON importer fails whereas the import is successful with the CSV importer.

Example of the attachment part in JSON:
"attachments" : [{
							"name" : "Doc1.docx",
							"attacher" : "zgraignic",
							"created" : "2014-04-30T13:51:11.400+0000",
							"uri" : "file://TeamPulse-attachment-598.docx"
						}, {
							"name" : "Doc1.docx",
							"attacher" : "zgraignic",
							"created" : "2014-07-22T06:55:37.253+0000",
							"uri" : "file://TeamPulse-attachment-707.docx"
						}
					],

Example of the attachment part in CSV:
id;Type;Status;summary;attachment1;attachment2
1;Bug;CLOSED;Summary;"2014-04-30 13:51;zgraignic;Doc1.docx;file://TeamPulse-attachment-598.docx";"2014-05-30 13:51;zgraignic;Doc1.docx;file://TeamPulse-attachment-707.docx"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64724].
  {panel}

h3. Environment
JIRA BTF 6.4.2 and JIM 6.3.4

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Go to *External System Import* screen in JIRA
Choose to import data from *Pivotal Tracker*
Proceed with the steps to complete the import process


h3. Expected Results
All the data is imported in JIRA and new fields are created in the target project if necessary


h3. Actual Results
All the data is created, but is also created a *External issue ID* and *External issue URL* custom fields for each import attempt. If the customer choose to import one project each time instead of importing all the projects together, JIRA will have lots of these fields at the end of the process.

Would be better if JIM could use the same custom field already created in the first import process instead of created a new one for each import.
fields.summary: Import data from Pivotal will create a External Issue url and External issue id for each import

fields.description: If any of the webwork actions in JIM's import setup steps return an "error" result -- perhaps when validation fails, or something more obtuse happens -- there is no view configured to render the errors. This results in a 404 being served, and the errors not being presented to the end-user.
fields.summary: No 'error' view set up for any of the import steps

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Import Issues from CSV does not respect Create Issue transition Validator in Workflow.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a workflow validator to the Create Issue transition, other than the Create Issue permission validator in a project/Issue type's workflow e.g. Close Issue permission validator or 3rd party validator.
# Try to import issues via CSV from the Issues Menu into that project/issuetype, without meeting the validation criteria e.g. user not having Close Issue permission
# Click the Validate Import button after submitting your CSV and/or configuration files
# Proceed to import.

h3. Expected Results
* Validate Import should report that no issue will be created since Create Issue validator restriction is not met.
* No issues should be created

h3. Actual Results
* Validate Import reports no issues, and promises to create issues
!Selection_005.jpg|thumbnail!
* Fatal error occurs due to NullPointerException when you proceed to import. 
!Selection_004.jpg|thumbnail!
* No clear error message is given to explain the cause of the exception. Detailed log records:
{code}
2015-09-26 01:52:50,882 INFO - Importer started!
2015-09-26 01:52:50,882 INFO - Engine is running in Import mode
2015-09-26 01:52:50,883 INFO - All issues will be imported to project: testcsvimport (TESCSV)
2015-09-26 01:52:50,884 INFO - Creating issue: [externalId='autoid-1673678947705695620', summary='CSV test']
2015-09-26 01:52:50,884 INFO - Issue does not have issue type selected, the affected issues will be created with default issue type [Task]
2015-09-26 01:52:50,894 ERROR - Fatal error during import
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.imports.bulkcreate.engine.BulkCreateDataImporter.doImportIssues(BulkCreateDataImporter.java:236)
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.imports.bulkcreate.engine.BulkCreateDataImporter.runImporterEngine(BulkCreateDataImporter.java:173)
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.imports.bulkcreate.engine.BulkCreateDataImporter.doImport(BulkCreateDataImporter.java:148)
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.imports.importer.impl.ImporterCallable.call(ImporterCallable.java:26)
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.imports.importer.impl.ImporterCallable.call(ImporterCallable.java:15)
	at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl$TaskCallableDecorator.call(TaskManagerImpl.java:528)
	at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl$TaskCallableDecorator.call(TaskManagerImpl.java:491)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
	at com.atlassian.jira.task.ForkedThreadExecutor$ForkedRunnableDecorator.run(ForkedThreadExecutor.java:254)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
{code}

h3. Workaround
* You would need a JIRA admin to check or remove the validator requirements in the Create Issue transition for the project's workflow.
fields.summary: Validate Import does not detect Create Issue transition Validator restrictions

h3. Summary
Importing issues using CSV returns error when username contains space

h3. Environment
* JIRA Cloud version {{7.1.0-OD-04-012}} 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user with a space in their username (e.g: john doe)
# Select *Import Issues from CSV* from *Issues* blue menu bar.
# Upload *CSV Source File*. Click _Next_.
# Select any project. Click _Next_.
# Map appropriate fields and click _Next_.
# Click _Validate_

h3. Expected Results
No error is retured.

h3. Actual Results
Error is returned:
{noformat}
The validation process has found 1 error/s:

Issue can't be created due to the error/s [ The reporter specified is not a user. ]
{noformat}

or
{noformat}
The validation process has found 1 error/s:

Issue can't be created due to the error/s [ User 'johndoe' does not exist. ]
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* Trying to escape the space with {{' '}} or {{" "}} or {{/ /}} doesn't work as well.

* The documentation on *Importing Issues* also does not specify whether this is allowed or not:
** https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracloud/importing-issues-737772291.html

h3.Workaround
* Remove the space in the username

fields.description:
h3. Summary
A customer is unable to complete project imports because they cannot create the "Trac Id" field in the target instance.  

h3. Environment
* JIRA 6.4.1.  Problem reproduced with JIM 6.3.0 and 7.0.13
* The XML backup for this customer is from their Cloud instance that they are migrating and merging into their production JIRA Data Center instance.
* The first step of this is to complete a full XML Restore into a temporary JIRA instance.  This has been done.  All other custom fields have been created in the target instance but the "Trac Id" field cannot be created because the "Bug Trac Id" 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Import Trac data using JIM.
# Create an XML Backup.
# Attempt to import a project that has issues imported from Trac

h3. Expected Results
* Installation of the JIM plugin should create the "Trac Id" field or make the "Bug Trac Id" field type available.

h3. Actual Results
* The custom field is not present and can't be created so the project cannot be imported.

h3.Workaround
* Delete this custom field from the Temp instance and create a new XML Backup, discarding the data from this field.  *This means that you will lose the issue IDs from the Trac bug reporting system.*

If this data is mission critical it may be possible to import the field values in CSV format.  This requires pulling the existing field values from the JIRA database but we have not fully investigated so instructions are not available at this time.
fields.summary: Unable to complete project imports in JIRA when issues have values in the "Trac Id" field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64703].
  {panel}

If you export a currency field from Excel to CSV you will get a record with a text like:
{code} 
" 5,790.14 "
"$ 5,790.14 "
"5,790.14 USD"
" (3,283.78)"
"56.71%"
" .2,431.70 ", 
(45.00) 
{code}

All the values presented above are not recognized as number even if they should.

The algorithm for converting them to numbers is not so complex, it requires removal of all characters that are not digits, decimal-dot (configurable), percent or (). If () are present the number will be negative and you can remove them. If percent is present you will remove it and divide the recognized number by 100. "10%" is always considered to be "0.1" float.

The idea is to call atof() only on something that was sanitized first.
fields.summary: CSV Import does fail to recognize different number formats including currency ones

WARN - Cannot add value [ Epic: Billing ] to CustomField Epic Link in Issue null. Probably value was in incorrect format

This means that now the only way to successfully import the data is to be sure that all Epics are listed before the other type of issues. 

Still this makes quite hard to prepare the JSON file. Think that in our case we are getting 15.000 issues.

It seems that an originalEstimate value of 11 hours ( "PT11H" ) is converted into "1d 4h" in JIRA instead of "1d 3h".

Any idea why this happens? JIRA is configured using the default 8 hours / day, 5 days a week.
Quote: Your current conversion rates are 1w = 5d and 1d = 8h.

Strange but this seems like a bug related to time-zone, as it happens that the server is using UTC locally and the client is using BST (GMT+1). Anyway, duration should have nothing to do with time-zone.
fields.summary: JIM JSON import of originalEstimate is doing unexpected round-up

fields.description:
# Create a custom field with a choice type. I tested with the Checkboxes and the Select List (single choice) type fields. I tested this issue with a Text Field type (multi line), and it didn't work.
# Set the field up to use only certain Issue Types. Just make sure that the type you choose also has the same type included in your CSV file. My field type utilized the Bug Issue Type. I tested with one, two, and three different types chosen at once. I reproduced each time.
# Have a CSV file with all the necessary fields to achieve an import cleanly. Just make sure there's a column for the custom field you just created.
# Map the fields.
# Instead of choosing the "Begin Import" button, you can choose "Validate".
# When you do, you should receive an error like this one:
{code}
Cannot add custom field value: null
The value [ {null=CustomValue} ] can't be added to the Custom Field [ CustomField ]. The value [ {null=CustomValue} ] can't be found or is in the incorrect format
{code}

Workaround:
Instead of choosing an Issue Type for the field configuration scheme when you configure the field, choose "Any issue type".
fields.summary: Import Issues from CSV only works for choice fields that are configured for global issue types

fields.description:
I only recently realized that this functionality is actually a bug, and does not seem to be intended functionality.

When using the admin level CSV import function the value in the "Issue Id" field is being saved to the External Issue ID field.  This means that unless you remove this value post-creation by editing issues, the next time you use the same value in the "Issue Id" for a CSV import, it is not treated as a new issue but an existing one, and is not created.  Any sub-tasks being created are now under the old issue instead of a new one, and any issues being linked are now linked to the old issue instead of a new one.

This only occurs with admin level CSV import, and does not occur with the new non-admin bulk create issue functionality.
fields.summary: When linking issues or creating sub-tasks under parent issues via csv import, Issue Id value is saved to External issue ID field
Check for creating a user named Unassigned or unassigned

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64697].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When the application context of a custom field is set to some specific project, the custom field will not appear in the mapping select list when doing a CSV import with issues of multiple projects.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom field with the name "TestCF".
# Configure the custom field by changing its application context from "Global context" to a specific project.
# Launch a CSV import by setting "Import to Project" to "Derfined in CSV" (see screenshot below)
 !2016-11-14_csv-config.png|thumbnail! 
# On the next page try to select the custom field "TestCF" from the mapping dropdown list.

h3. Expected Results
"TestCF" appears in the dropdown list

h3. Actual Results
"TestCF" missing in the dropdown list unless we change the "Import to Project" setting to the project which the context of custom field is defined to.
 
h3.Workaround
Temporarily change the context of custom field to "Global context" when doing the CSV import, and revert the change after the import is done.
fields.summary: Custom field without Global context does not appear in the map list when importing CSV file with multiple projects

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64696].
  {panel}

I tried importing the following JSON. The "items" member of the first history element is an object rather than the expected array. 

{code}
{
    "projects": [
        {
            "name": "Kanban Sample",
            "key": "KBS",
            "description": "Kanban Sample",
            "workflowSchemeName": "GreenHopper Workflow Scheme",
            "issues": [
                {
                    "history": [
                        {
                            "created": "P3D",
                            "items": {
                                "fieldType": "jira",
                                "field": "status",
                                "from": "1",
                                "fromString": "Open",
                                "to": "10001",
                                "toString": "Selected for Development"
                            }
                        },
                        {
                            "created": "P2D",
                            "items": {
                                "fieldType": "jira",
                                "field": "status",
                                "from": "10001",
                                "fromString": "Selected for Development",
                                "to": "10004",
                                "toString": "In Development"
                            }
                        },
                        {
                            "created": "P1D",
                            "items": {
                                "fieldType": "jira",
                                "field": "status",
                                "from": "10004",
                                "fromString": "In Development",
                                "to": "6",
                                "toString": "Closed"
                            }
                        }
                    ],
                    "summary": "Instructions for deleting this sample board and project are in the description for this card",
                    "issueType": "Story",
                    "status": "Closed",
                    "description": "*To Delete the Sample Project (Must be performed by a user with Administration rights)* \n- Open the administration interface by clicking \"Administration\" at the top right \n- Under the Projects section, click \"All Projects\" \n- Select the \"Delete\" link for this project\n\n*To Delete this Rapid Board (Must be performed by the owner of this Rapid Board or an Administrator)*\n- Click the Cog at the top right of this board\n- Select \"Delete\"",
                    "priority": "Major",
                    "created": "P7D",
                    "comments": [
                        {
                            "body": "Created 7 days ago"
                        },
                        {
                            "body": "Open to Selected for Development 3 days ago\r\nSelected for Development to In Development 2 days ago\r\nIn Development to Closed 1 days ago"
                        }
                    ]
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
}
{code}

That results in the following stack trace (the import cannot be aborted and the plugin needs to be manually disabled and re-enabled in order to continue):

fields.description:
When using Issue ID and Parent ID to create sub-tasks, it seems that the Issue ID is permanently stored as some kind of issue key.
So after the first import, if I try to import other issues using the same Issue ID, JIM will consider that the issue already exist and refuse to import it.
Several people had the same problem:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/24386/import-into-jira-creating-sub-tasks-using-issue-id

So it seems that we have 3 fields doing more or less the same thing: Issue key, Issue ID and External Issue ID.
If this is a feature, I suggest that the documentation be updated to clarify this point.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64692].
  {panel}

Copied from https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-32034

While importing a CSV file into existing project (defined in CSV), user gets the error message attached, as follows:
{panel:bgColor=#FFCCFF|borderStyle=none}
Invalid project key TP: Project key or name is already used. If you want to import to an existing project the name and the key must match it exactly.
{panel}
What happens in this case is that the project name and key are case sensitive, which means that the second part of the message is accurate ("project the name and the key must match it exactly"), but the first part of this error message is quite confusing, stating that there's an invalid project key, and also that the project name or key are already in use. That does not make sense.

Steps to replicate:
# Create a project named *Test Project*
# Create CSV file such as 
{noformat}
Project Name,Project Key,Summary
TEST PROJECT,TP,testing CSV
{noformat}
(!) Note that the project name in capital letters is intentional
# In JIRA, choose CSV File import, choose the CSV created in step 2, click next
# Select *Defined in CSV* for _Import to JIRA Project_ option, click next
# Map the fields accordingly, click next
# The error is displayed.
fields.summary: User gets an unclear error message while importing CSV file into existing project

fields.description:
When importing a project from pivotal tracker into a new project if you manually enter a value in lower case for the key it displays in upper case but doesn't validate (see attached error). 

Steps:

1. Import project from pivotal (may need to create account on pivotal)
2. Select create new to import to

Workaround is to enter the key manually in uppercase

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64682].
  {panel}

JDOG in German - JIM has not German translations.  

This is odd because JIM is bundled which means that it's message files were supplied to NZTC for translation.

Looking in TAC you also see translations - https://translations.atlassian.com/dashboard/translate?lang=de_DE#/11/4111/0/ALL/ALL/jira-importer-plugin

However they are not appearing on the JIM pages....

The same can be repeated on BTF instance.

In JIM project there are translation files that are incomplete.
I believe that JIRA is loading TAC and than loading those files from JIM.
Because those local files are incomplete it overrides some translations with default (English) ones.

It may be that removing all translations from JIM project will help (except English of course)
fields.summary: Problem with translations in JIM

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64681].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When importing issues through a CSV file, if there is a semicolon (\;) on the attachment name, the import will fail with the following error: *Cannot parse FILEINFO as attachment info: too many tokens*. This fails even if you quote the file name as in "file;name.jpg", it will still fail.

h3. Expected Results

The import concludes normally.

h3. Actual Results
The error bellow is displayed on the conclusion screen for the import process:
{noformat}
Cannot parse 'ATTACHMENT INFO' as attachment info: too many tokens
{noformat}
 
h3.Workaround
Remove the semicolon from the attachment name.
fields.summary: Cannot import with semicolon on attachment name

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When we import CSV data into JIRA via System External Import, fields with duplicate names will be somehow mapped to Custom field rather than the System field even if I choose the correct field during the import.

I suspect there is a bug in the CSV Importer around the name of a custom field when selecting it for import, particularly if there is a standard field by the same name.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom field named "Status". Not a good idea, but that's what was done.
# Create a CSV file for import with Issue ID, reporter, summary, status columns.
# Use the CSV importer to import the CSV file, mapping as expected. Select the standard JIRA field Status for the status column.
# Note that the custom field named Status is selected since it is named as a custom field, not a standard field in the CSV Importer mapping.

h3. Expected Results
The System field Status should have been updated.

h3. Actual Results
The Custom field Status have been updated.

h3.Workaround
*Option 1*
# Map the fields again a second time on the same Field selection screen.

*Option 2*
# Rename the Custom Field to a different name before the import.
# Perform the CSV import.
# Rename back the Custom field back to the original name.

*Option 3*
# Make sure the field's context does not include the project/issue type you are importing the CSV into.
fields.summary: CSV Importer gets fields confused

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64672].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create a test CSV file with values like "ç", "ã", "á", "ê".
# In the CSV import page from JIRA, choose this file to import.

h3. Current behaviour

# If you keep the default collation (UTF-8), the characters will be handled as "??", like:
#- Refeição - "Refei??o"
#- Salários - "Sal?rios"
# If you change the collation to latin characters (ISO-8859-1), the characters will disappear, as:
#- Refeição - "Refeio"
#- Salários - "Salrios"

h3. Expected behaviour

Import the characters correctly in any of the collations.
fields.summary: CSV import doesn't handle latin characters in any collation
Remove no longer necessary warning from Mantis Setup page

fields.description:
When using a basic create issue validator CSV imports always encounter a fatal error. When the validator is removed the CSV imports correctly. We are simply trying to prevent ~100s - 2,000 duplicates a day from being created due to having to import tickets from a legacy ticketing system

[Atlassian Answers link|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/38530358/csv-issue-imports-encounter-fatal-error-during-import-w-validator]


Basic validator -> "Validation based on JQL query"
{code:java}
project = "Project Name" AND summary ~ "%{00000}"
{code}
Boolean expression tested:
{code:java}
{00058} = 0
{code}





Here is what a user would see if importing a standard issue

fields.description:
Although the Pivotal Tracker Import Wizard does not allow me to select an existing project when that project is not already associated with the *PT Workflow Scheme*, it does allow me to select projects which are not associated with the *PT Issue Type Scheme* (e.g. I can select a project that's associated with the *PT Workflow Scheme*, but is also associated with JIRA's *Default Issue Type Scheme*).

After importing the PT issues into an existing JIRA project (which associated with the *Default Issue Type Scheme*), then by the end of the import, I see issues types in this project such as Chore, which are only made available by the *PT Issue Type Scheme*. However, this project is still associated with the *Default Issue Type Scheme* (in which Chore is not available).

*How to resolve...*

Make the *PT Issue Type Scheme* an additional requirement to the *PT Workflow Scheme* for an existing JIRA project, before such a JIRA project can be selected during the Pivotal Tracker Import Wizard as a recipient project for such issues.
fields.summary: When importing PT issues, a JIRA admin can still select a an existing JIRA project (which doesn't use the 'PT Issue Type Scheme') to import these issues to, which leads to an erroneous import.

fields.description:
*+Steps to reproduce+*
# create a simple CSV file, using *Open* for Status mapping:
{code}
Key,Summary,Issue Type,Status,Priority,Created,Description
CSV-1,CSV Test,Bug,Open,Critical,5/11/2015 14:50,Import this plz
{code}
# go to Administration -> System -> External System Import -> Import from CSV
# import this file and map all the fields properly (no need to map field values)

*+Expected behavior+*
Fields are mapped properly and issue is imported

*+Actual behavior+*
Status cannot be mapped and issue is not imported:
-> [^failure.txt]
{code}Caused by: com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.external.ExternalException: Cannot find status with id 'Open'.{code}
(x) "ID is required but Name is found"

*+Workaround 1+*
Use Status ID instead of Name in CSV e.g.:
# go to Administration -> Issues -> Statuses
# hover the mouse onto the Edit link of the Status to be mapped
# notice the Status ID in the status bar of the browser e.g. for Open it's 1
(i) alternatively, all Status IDs can be searched from JIRA database:
{code}SELECT pname, id FROM issuestatus;{code}
# replace Open with 1 in the CSV file and import it
-> [^success.txt]

*+Workaround 2+*
Downgrade JIRA Importers Plugin (JIM) to 6.2.8 (compatible with JIRA 6.2 -> 6.3.15 only)
(!) JIM-1391 is not available in JIM 6.2.8
# uninstall JIM from Manage add-ons
# download [^jira-importers-plugin-6.2.8.jar]
# use Upload add-on from Manage add-ons to upload the file manually
# reindex JIRA
-> Status can be mapped using Status Name e.g. Open now
fields.summary: Cannot Import Status using Status Name in CSV

fields.description:
Bitbucket importer is initiating project export on Bitbucket side. 
This export can be then manually canceled by user on Bitbucket.
Importer will not know about it and is not prepared for an export status message returned from Bitbucket.

This is trivial because no one sane should cancel export that moment. And even if he does importer will just fail and quit - export can be just repeat another time.
So maybe it's not worth it to fix it at all.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
JIRA's Redmine importer doesn't import Issue Custom Fields of version format.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
* Using the Redmine Importer, import issues from a project with Version Customfields (issue customfields, of version format)
* Complete the steps for External Import, and allow JIRA to map the Version Custom field to a new Custom Field in JIRA of type version picker (JIRA would do this automatically).


h3. Expected Results
JIRA should import data from that custom field into the mapped JIRA custom field.


h3. Actual Results
JIRA completes the import, but doesn't import the custom field data. The following WARN message is thrown in the atlassian-jira.log file:
{noformat}
2015-09-22 20:50:18,041 JiraTaskExectionThread-4 WARN admin 1250x3305x1 a2kdmd 127.0.0.1 /secure/admin/ImporterLogsPage!import.jspa [imports.importer.impl.AbstractDataImporter$1Thread[http-bio-8641-exec-20,5,main]] Cannot add value [ 4 ] to CustomField VersionName in Issue with summary 'test redmine version field'. Probably value was in incorrect format
{noformat}
fields.summary: Redmine Version Customfield cannot be imported into JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64656].
  {panel}

It's great that the newer versions of JIM can create the required mappings, field values, and so on. However, this poses a problem when the user is importing a project on a production system and is not looking carefully at the data.

For example, assume that I've prepared a configuration file that corresponds to a particular type of CSV template. I've tested and verified that the mapping works.

Later, I get a new CSV file from a user that conforms to my previously-generated template, but it contains an incorrect value for one of the field values (say, an incorrect Resolution value). When I go to process the CSV file with JIM, it will go ahead and happily create a new Resolution (which applies to the entire JIRA instance), even if this resolution was just a typo that was meant to be another real resolution. This happens silently, which can lead to other non-localized problems (such as users entering the incorrect resolution values in entirely unrelated projects).

Before beginning the final import process, JIM should warn the user that it is about to create field value 'xxx' for custom field 'yyy', which would eliminate this problem.
fields.summary: JIM needs to warn users before creating new field values

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64655].
  {panel}

Any data exported by JSON Exporter does not include Security Level informations. This means that all imported data by JSON has Security Level set to 'None'. This issue also concerns importing - user cannot specify Security informations

Steps to reproduce:

1. Make sure you have a project with defined Security Levels (e.g. 'None' and 'abc-staff').
2. Create Issue A which is only visible for abc-staff
3. Create Issue B which is visible for everyone
4. Add comment to Issue B which will be visible only for abc-staff
5. List Both issues on Search screen
6. Export Issues to JSON (make sure that user who performs the export has abc-staff permissions)
7. Import exported data in step 6. to other project / other JIRA instance

Expected Version 1: Imported data in step 7. has the same security Levels that had the source issues.
Expected Version 2: Exproted data in step 6. has skipped secured Informations so they are not imported in step 7.

Actual: There is none Security-Level informations is JSON, Step 6. exports all data that is visible for the user who performs the export. Step 7. imports all data with Security Level 'None'.
fields.summary: JSON Export to include Security Informations

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64654].
  {panel}

I have found a severe missing feature (or bug) in the JIRA-bugzilla importer.

during the import actions about the attachment (e.g.
- WHO
- DID what
- and WHEN
with the attachment
are _not_ recorded

this makes it impossible to see, e.g. who added the attachment.

while it has been implemented meanwhile in JIRA itself to see a bit information about attachment actions, the importer forgets to record that information.

below is a simple example: the information who created the attachment is lost in JIRA

>>>> bugzilla <<<<
attachment 1699 created (attachment 1699 [details])
comment for the attachment

usual bug report text
>>>> bugzilla <<<<

>>>> jira <<<<
usual bug report text
>>>> jira <<<<
fields.summary: bugzilla importer forgets to record attachment operations during import

  {panel}

We have a custom importer which connects to external JIRA and imports the issues. 

We are also using CSV importer.

When Issues contains remote links and web links they are not copied.
It seems remote and weblinks are not handled in JIM.

It would be good to add this feature which is applicable to CSV, JSON and other importers as well
fields.summary: Remote and web links are not handled in JIM

  {panel}

As a admin, i would like to import issues into projects via CSV without affecting/changing the updated date/time of the issue after importing worklogs. 

The current feature allows me to import worklogs, with a specific date when the worklog has happened.
But due to worklogs being imported as a separate action, all imported issues with imported worklogs have updated date changed to the import date and time just because the worklog has happened.

Therefore, for resolved/closed issues of a couple of years back, it is weird to see from the issue activity that the assignee has a worklog from 2 years back that was reported/added 2 years later.

Please see the attachment image. Thank you.

Unable to import the same field from a CSV file to two different field in JIRA.

Why? There is a very good use-case for this: Considering that the "Summary" field is required, you may want to import some other field inside the summary but at the same time you still need to keep this field at this proper place.

Now, if you select one field for one mapping Jira will not let you configure the same field again.

Clearly the current behavior was more life a "feature", but not quite an useful one.
fields.summary: Ability to import the same field from a CSV file to two different fields in JIRA
